title: Scoreboard: Nike's big bet will define a Silicon Valley veteran
text:
In the first edition of Scoreboard this year, we take you behind Nike's ambitious restructuring plan, look at how US capital is Americanising two European leagues, and the high-stakes football match that must happen for the sake of US college sports.

Send us tips and feedback at scoreboard@ft.com. Not already receiving the email newsletter? Sign up here. For everyone else, let's go. 

Inside Nike's identity crisis

A year ago this month, Nike handed the reins of chief executive of the world's largest sportswear company to the Silicon Valley veteran John Donahoe. Like many CEOs, he's had to guide the business through the unexpected forces of a global pandemic and widespread social unrest during 2020. But he also inherited a company in the midst of a years-long transformation.

Nike's identity crisis is the subject of this weekend's FT Magazine cover story, which explores the twin challenges of its internal struggles with diversity and adapting its $37bn business to the world of ecommerce. It's well worth reading in full.

It's also worth taking a closer look at Nike's results during Donahoe's first year. For one thing, Nike is forecasting percentage point revenue growth in the low-teens for the fiscal year ending in May 2021. For another, “demand creation” — Nike jargon for the money it spends on marketing, sponsorships, and contracts — will increase as a percentage of overall revenue in the coming months.  

Both forecasts are bullish for any retailer during a worsening global pandemic, let alone one whose pendulum has swung as widely as Nike's: from a $790m loss for the quarter ended in May last year to a profit of $1.3bn for the period ended in November. 

They are underpinned by a restructuring launched by Donahoe in June, which effectively put an end to developing products by sport (running, football, basketball, etc) and instead organises products by target customer: men, women, and children. 

Current and former employees say that transition poses a big risk. “What makes Nike magical is that it has real athlete insight from each sport” said Musa Tariq, a former marketer at Nike. “That is what I am most curious to see — whether Nike can remain as relevant to their customers without [these categories]".

Meanwhile, Nike increasingly controls its own destiny in everything from retailing to marketing. In 2011, just 16 per cent of Nike products were sold directly to consumers; by last year, that figure was 35 per cent. Over the same period, Nike went from holding the outfitting rights to 0 of 4 major US pro sports leagues to paying billions each year for 3 of 4 (the National Football League, the National Basketball Association, and Major League Baseball). 

If any company can navigate such challenges — a pandemic, a fundamental retail revolution, its marketing contracts — it may be Nike. But no one expects it to be easy. 

The creeping Americanisation of the EPL and F1

Recent investments have left two British sports teams looking more American. The competitions in which they compete already featured a growing number of US investors.

Neither the coronavirus pandemic nor Brexit deterred ALK Capital from buying 84 per cent of Burnley, an unglamorous Premier League football club in the north west of England, or MSP Sports Capital late last year from acquiring a minority stake in McLaren Racing, which competes in car racing series Formula One.

The two competitions have been insulated from the worst of the pandemic because unlike rugby and baseball, they can rely on billions of dollars' worth of broadcasting contracts.

A £200m price tag was put on Burnley in a deal partly financed by a unit of MSD Partners, an investment firm with ties to computing entrepreneur Michael Dell, while McLaren Racing was valued at £560m.

ALK managing partner Alan Pace said the global appeal of the Premier League, the world's richest domestic football competition, was critical to his investment.

“I've been around the world,” said Pace. “You can always see the Premier League . . . that's pretty special.”

Did the pandemic give him pause? “Probably every other day for about a year,” he said, admitting that it took time to take stock of the pandemic-induced three-month suspension of the 2019/20 season, which cost teams hundreds of millions of pounds in rebates to broadcasters.

As for Brexit, which will prevent clubs from signing players freely from the EU, Pace hinted that Burnley could partner with an overseas club to compensate.

US investors are also pouring money into another global sport: F1, where it used to be rare to see American-owned teams. Haas's debut in 2016 was the first by an American F1 team since 1986. But last August, New York-based fund Dorilton Capital bought Williams Racing, ending decades of family ownership. 

That was followed by MSP's decision to take an initial 15 per cent stake in McLaren, rising to a third after two years, alongside the Najafi Companies and UBS O'Connor.

Then there's the ownership of F1 itself. Liberty Media, the US group controlled by billionaire John Malone, bought the car racing circus in an $8bn deal completed four years ago this month, but has struggled to add more Grands Prix in the country.

Aston Martin F1, the team owned by Canadian billionaire Lawrence Stroll, this week partnered with the US-headquartered IT services company Cognizant, which wants to grow outside its home market through a sport that attracted a global television audience of more than 400m viewers in 2019.

“In the years ahead, Formula One will become even stronger in the United States,” Stroll, whose son Lance drives for the team, told Scoreboard. 

College football championship kicks off year of financial uncertainty

Pandemic permitting, Monday will be the kick-off of the US national college football championship, between the perennial favourite Alabama Crimson Tide and the Big Ten conference winner Ohio State Buckeyes.

That both teams are even able to contest the game — Ohio State has experienced a Covid-19 outbreak over the past week — is remarkable, considering the season almost didn't happen. But more than crowning a champion, the title game carries huge consequences for the financial future of dozens of US universities with prominent sports programmes.

The College Football Playoff is the organisation which negotiates media rights for participating schools and their regional conferences in addition to forming the selection committee for the invitational championship. 

According to the college sports advocacy group Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics, the contract to broadcast college football with ESPN is worth $7.3bn over 12 years, and paid out more than $460m to participating conferences and their schools — more than 100 in total — last year.

Naturally, those terms have been disrupted by the effects of Covid-19. Nick Carparelli, executive director for the entire college football advocating body Bowl Season, said contracts between bowl operators which host the games and conferences were “scrapped” and renegotiated for this year only. Sixteen of the season's 44 bowl games were cancelled due to the pandemic.

American football and basketball are largely the only revenue-generating sports in the vast, $8bn US collegiate athletic programme. Football in particular is unique in that only conferences with bowl contracts earn lucrative media payments, while those without — such as the Ivy League teams — do not.

But most universities with sports programs are already hurting after the 2020 cancellation of March Madness, the annual basketball tournament and the single-largest revenue driver in college sports. As such, the National Collegiate Athletic Association slashed disbursements to universities from $600m to just $225m.

The near-term future looks cloudy: this week the NCAA said it plans to stage the 2021 March Madness entirely in a bubble environment in the city of Indianapolis, in an effort to salvage its moneymaker.

Mike Krzyzewski, head coach of the men's basketball team at Duke University, told ESPN radio over the summer that a potential cancellation of the 2021 tournament was a matter of financial survival: “We need to have the tournament. We can't have it where two years in a row you don't have the NCAA tournament.”

This week's highlights

  • Atlanta pastor Raphael Warnock won his race for a US Senate seat in Georgia this week, defeating Women's National Basketball Association team owner Kelly Loeffler. It was the League's players who defined the race for Warnock this summer, as four-time WNBA champ Sue Bird recounted to the FT. 

  • The Premier League is committed to completing its season without a “circuit breaker” or outright cancellation, as it seeks to protect vital broadcast revenues despite rising Covid-19 cases among players and wider society.

  • Entain, which owns bookmaker Ladbrokes Coral, agreed to buy Swedish sports betting company Enlabs for £250m. The deal came days after Entain rejected an £8bn takeover proposal from US casino giant MGM Resorts.

  • Discovery launched its streaming service in the US and parts of Europe this week, in a bet that this will be the year for the postponed Tokyo Olympics, the broadcast rights to which the media giant paid €1.3bn through 2024. 

  • Private capital's big rush into sports holdings was one of the biggest trends of 2020. With a potential Spac merger for Fenway Sports Group and institutional investment funds hunting for NBA stakes, what will 2021 yield?

Transfer Market

  • There's new leadership at Sky, the main broadcaster of the Premier League in the UK, with Jeremy Darroch stepping away from day-to-day running of the company following its takeover by Comcast in 2018. Dana Strong, the head of Comcast's residential US cable business, will succeed him as Sky's chief executive.

  • Colin Graves, who oversaw major governance reforms and secured a £1.1bn broadcasting deal for English cricket in his time as chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, has joined the advisory board of Oakwell Sports Advisory.

  • Tim Godfrey joins the Professional Triathlete's Organisation as chief marketing officer, after serving in a similar role at the global sailing championship, SailGP.

Final Whistle

It isn't every day that an elite male athlete at the top of his game cites a woman as his athletic inspiration — which is what Alabama running back Najee Harris did shortly before his Crimson Tide defeated Notre Dame in the college football semi-final. In a press conference, he said he looks up to US footballer Megan Rapinoe for her activism outside of sport, to which the World Cup champion replied on Twitter, “hurdle someone for me!” Of course, like any good receiver, he delivered. 

Scoreboard is written by Samuel Agini, Murad Ahmed and Arash Massoudi in London, Sara Germano, James Fontanella-Khan, and Anna Nicolaou in New York, with contributions from the team that produce the Due Diligence newsletter, the FT's global network of correspondents and data visualisation team.
